body_html:
OK, maybe I can rephrase this.
As python code simply needs to be copied by cmake, and no compilation or other processing is needed, old files that do not exist anymore are just noop statements, they will try copying but will immediately return success because there is nothing to copy.
For anything else, the build will fail because it will try compiling a non-existent file, or something similar.

Either way, either the entries are noops, or get caught by the build.
The change you have should be able to catch all noops, anything else should be caught by the cmake build.

body:
OK, maybe I can rephrase this.
As python code simply needs to be copied by cmake, and no compilation or other processing is needed, old files that do not exist anymore are just noop statements, they will try copying but will immediately return success because there is nothing to copy.
For anything else, the build will fail because it will try compiling a non-existent file, or something similar.

Either way, either the entries are noops, or get caught by the build.
The change you have should be able to catch all noops, anything else should be caught by the cmake build.
